content: The "Deductibility and Incentives to Promote Learning Opportunities and Maximize Assistance (DIPLOMA) Act of 2006" allows for a deduction for higher education expenses. The "DIPLOMA Act of 2006" eliminates the dollar limitation for the deduction of qualified tuition and related expenses based on adjusted gross income. Taxpayers with adjusted gross income over $80,000 ($160,000 for joint returns) will not be eligible for the deduction. Expansion of Deduction for Interest on Education Loans to Include Principal Payments, amending Section 221 of the Internal Revenue Code to allow deduction for both interest and principal paid on qualified education loans. A limit is set on the period deduction allowed for principal payments after the first 60 months, treating any loan and refinancings as one. The amendment to Section 221 of the Internal Revenue Code allows deduction for both interest and principal payments on qualified education loans, with a limit set on the period deduction allowed for principal payments after the first 60 months. Multiple loans refinanced or serviced as a single loan are treated as one for this purpose. SEC. 4. EARNED TUITION CREDIT. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include the Earned Tuition Credit, which provides a tax credit for qualified tuition and related expenses paid by the taxpayer for an eligible student. The credit is 100% of expenses up to $1,500 and 50% of expenses exceeding $1,500 but not exceeding $4,000. The earned tuition credit is limited to 4 taxable years for an eligible student. The credit is only allowed if the individual is at least a half-time student for part of the year. The earned tuition credit is limited to 4 taxable years for an eligible student, only if they are at least a half-time student for part of the year. Credit is not allowed if the student has completed the first 4 years of postsecondary education or if they have been convicted of a felony drug offense.
